John Smith wrote:

> Chapter 10 does not apply to my problem because its
> just about JDBC.

I don't think it is: it uses JDBC as the primary vehicle, but the 
underlying concepts work elsewhere.

> Please consider that we don't use Entity Beans
> directly. We use a very unknown (and very bad in my
> opinion) framework called JCoffee which uses Entity
> Beans (CMP of course) internally.
> 
> Since I don't know very much about "native" Entity
> Beans, it is maybe hard to describe to you our design.

It's not so important how data access happens. (This is what I mean by 
the previous comment.) What matters is that it happens behind an 
interface that your data access clients (business logic, usually) can 
substitute at run time.

> Okay, I'll read Chapter 11 and come back to you if it
> doesn't solve my question.

I'll do my best.

> But can you (or someone else) please tell me this:

> - Do you test validation rules with JUnit (such as
> maxLength(10))?

What does it mean to test these validation rules? Pretend you could do 
it easily; what would the test look like? This will help me understand 
enough to respond.

> - Do you test your Java finder methods (internally EJB
> QL, HQL, SQL or whatever)?

I generally need to know whether the implementation of the finder 
returns the proper result set, so yes.

> - Do you test pre-initializations of business objects
> instances (like Article, Customer...)?

Can you say this differently? I don't understand it as is.
--
